J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Andrew McDonagh wrote:
>   
>> amine achergui wrote:
>>  > Hi everyone,
>>  > I'm now using as for mocking jmock but i want to know if it's the best
>>  > choice.
>>  >  
>>
>> Personally.....none.
>>
>> Using IntelliJ or Eclipse, its so easy to Fake an Interface or to derive
>> one class from another in order to stub out its methods, the Mock
>> frameworks just aren't worth it.
>>
>> This is especially true if you are new to TDD or Unit testing.
>>     
>
> Really? I know it's easy to generate an anonymous implementation of 
> ResultSet, but do you really want 350+ lines of code when all you need 
> to do is fake out next() returning false?
>
>   

Really....it depends..  :)

In the cases where I've had interfaces with that amount of methods to 
stub (Corba ones are full of them) then yes its still easy.
I've configured Eclipse (in about 2 mins) to insert:

 throw new RuntimeException("${enclosing_type}.${enclosing_method}() not 
yet implemented - faked for unit tests");


into each method that the auto code generator creates when asked to 
implement and interface or extend a class.

So instantly I have a java fake/mock where every method is faked - all 
auto generated.

e.g.


public interface GettingEm {
    public boolean goGetIt(String id);
}



public class FakeGettingEm implements GettingEm {

    public boolean goGetIt(String id) {
        throw new RuntimeException("FakeGettingEm.goGetIt() not yet 
implemented - faked for unit tests");
    }

}



Now the depends part.....

As any class with that amount of methods (00s) is suspect IMO, so I tend 
to wrapper the actual interface/class that I'm trying to use with my own 
much smaller interface - essentially hiding the dependency of the 
ResultSet, CORBA POA, etc from my own code.  My interface/wrapper class 
is then tiny - and so a mocking framework just aint worth it.

> For tiny interfaces, especially with only one method, I can't argue with 
> you, 
cool!

> but after about 3 methods, jMock is much more compact.
>   
our mileage variance is a little different then :)

Andrew
